title: How to factorize (x-y) ² + (y-x) ² - Quora

response.answer_text: How do you factorize (x-y) ² + (y-x) ²? Note that (x-y) ² = (y-x) ²(Why?  Hint : (-1) ²= 1) So: (x-y) ² + (y-x) ² = 2 * (x-y) ² Or, also: 2*(y-x) ² Factorization: 2 * (x-y) * (x-y)

Expand the expression and an amazing thing happens. I’m going to let you figure out why. (x-y)^2 +(y-x)^2 =[x^2 -2xy +y^2 ] + [y^2 -2xy+x^2] =2x^2 -4xy +2y^2 =2(x-y)^2 OR 2(y-x)^2 I read it as 2 times the difference of between x and y, squared. Remember, x^2 =(-x)^2 and when working with real numbers is always positive.
